description: Compare Scots dandill (“to dander; go about idly; move uncertainly; trifle”), English dialectal dander (“to wander about; talk incoherently; rave”), Middle Dutch dantinnen (“to trifle”) (from French dandiner (“to swing; waddle”)), German dändeln, tändeln (“to trifle, dandle”), Middle Dutch and Provincial German danten (“to do foolish things; trifle”), German Tand (“trifle, prattle”).

verbs.description: dandle (third-person singular simple present dandles, present participle dandling, simple past and past participle dandled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move up and down on one's knee or in one's arms, in affectionate play, usually said of a child.
examples: You will nurse and be carried on her arm and dandled on her knees.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat with fondness or affection, as if a child; to pet.
examples: [T]hey have put me in a silk night-gown and gaudy fool's cap, and make me now and then stand in the window with it. I am ashamed to be dandled thus, and cannot look in the glass without blushing to see myself turned into such a pretty little master.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To play with; to wheedle.
